properties.name: Albany, MO
properties.description: Posted by InstantaneousLived here for a summer or two while I was in college, because my parents moved here. Interesting local character, to say the least. An annual river festival and "anvil ringing" are some of the town\'s major events. There is a neat old courthouse in the center of the town square. Dramatically rolling farmland and the biggest skies you\'ve ever seen. Great huge storms roll across the open plains in the summer, and you can see anviled thunderheads piling up from miles and miles away.

properties.name: Carleton College, Northfield, MN
properties.description: Posted by InstantaneousI got my undergrad degree here at this small Liberal Arts school. The town\'s motto is "Cows, Colleges and Contentment." There is a Malto-Meal factory in town and it smells like oats in the winter. Ultimate Frisbee, "progressives," and "traying" are some of the College\'s main pastimes. There is a rival academic institution in town, St. Olaf\'s, made famous by the character Rose from the TV show, the Golden Girls. The rumor is that a Carleton grad used to be a writer on the show...

properties.name: Christopher & Greenwich, West Village, New York City, NY
properties.description: Posted by Instantaneous Second apartment in New York City. Much larger space and only one roommate. This building may have at one time in the 50s or 60s been the site of the famous Harlem collage artist Romare Bearden\'s first art show. Yoko Ono first showed around here in the 60s, too. We had a lot of mice because we lived above a restaurant. I once caught two on the same glue trap. The infamous "Two Potato" bar used to be right next door. It was known for its transvestite lounge acts and who knows what else. The bar was also extremely loud, frequently annoying me at 3am. I was living here when the WTC was attacked in 2001. The Archive Building, where the infamous Monica Lewinsky lives(d), is right across the street. I never ran into her, myself.

properties.name: Dallas-Ft. Worth, TX
properties.description: Posted by Instantaneous I was really little. My Dad was transferred here fro work, and I think we were only here for a summer. Texas summers are brutally hot and humid. I had a fort I had built into the closet of my room.

properties.name: East 12th St, East Village, New York City , NY
properties.description: Posted by Instantaneous3rd Apartment in New York. Moved back with the same roommate to a great 2-bedroom in the East Village. It had 3 rooms with street-facing windows- lots of great light. A lot more new restaurants and bars had opened up in our absence. Would wake up to the sounds of kids playing in the schoolyard right across the street and the Hispanic families gossiping loudly on the front sidewalk. There was (and still is) a nice little authentic French bistro called Resto Leon just down the street- the beautiful people would often spill out on to sidewalk cafe at night, drinking wine and smoking.

properties.name: East 13th St, East Village, New York City, NY
properties.description: Posted by Instantaneous My first apartment in New York City. It was a funky rehabbed 3-bedroom on the 6th floor of a 6-floor walkup. I had great calves as a result of climbing all of those stairs and also didn\'t want to leave very much. My room was a box built on the roof with a deck outside. That was pretty cool, until someone broke in and then torched all of my stuff. I lost everything I owned. Oh well, it makes for a great NYC story. I still remember the great views we had and watching the sun rise over Brooklyn and the East River.

properties.name: Edinburgh, Scotland, UK
properties.description: Posted by InstantaneousEdinburgh, Scotland

properties.name: First Sound, then Sight
properties.description: Posted by Instantaneous147 Christopher St, New York, NYListening to the sirens roaring down the West Side Highway, then seeing both towers billowing smoke outside on the corner, looking directly down Greenwich Street. People were setting up cameras on tripods to capture photos, which seemed wrong to me at the time.

properties.description: Posted by Instantaneous

properties.name: Hinsdale, IL - A Suburb of Chicago
properties.description: Posted by Instantaneous I basically "grew up" here. It\'s a very safe, sleepy, affluent commuter village. I was here from the middle of First Grade through High School. My dad and uncle built a side addition to our house on their own. We had an alley which ran behind the houses, so all of the garages were in the back. It\'s a very Chicago thing.

properties.name: Kansas City, MO
properties.description: Posted by InstantaneousWas here for Kindergarten. We lived near a busy corner where there were often car crashes. The house was a cute little Tudor on a little inclined lot. I got my first dog here. We didn\'t have a TV.

properties.name: Outside Waynesboro, VA
properties.description: Posted by InstantaneousWaynesboro, VAI was born on a working farm here, across the road from my Grandparents\' house. The farm I was born on is called the Grove Farm.

properties.name: Porter Square, Cambridge, MA
properties.description: Posted by Instantaneous My first apartment out of college was here. I shared a 3-bedroom attic apartment with my girlfriend at the time and 2 other roommates, all of whom had gone to Carleton. It was a crazy place to live for 4 people, located right behind the Star Market in Porter Square. I used to take the "T" out to Alewife for work. The Porter Sq T station is insanely deep, requiring a descent down two very long escalators. Boston is a city focused around Squares. It\'s very New Englandy. Bostonians have candlepin bowling, which sometimes requires one to "use the wood." The day my girlfriend and I broke up, I went and saw "American Pie" at the Davis Sq. movie theater, which wasn\'t the best way to ease the pain. I moved to New York City not long after that.

properties.name: President St, Columbia Waterfront District, Brooklyn, NY
properties.description: Posted by InstantaneousMy 4th apt in New York. Made the leap out of Manhattan to a one-bedroom in Brooklyn. Cheaper rent, more space, trees and much quieter. At first I missed the energy of the city, but I really like having my own space- living by myself for the first time since, well, ever, basically. I found a funky storefront apt that has a big plate glass window in the front and a door that opens onto the street. The neighborhood is a small slice of Italian families living between the water and the BQE. Very nice people, along with a few artists here and there. There are a few interesting bars and restaurants around, and it\'s only a short walk to Court and Smith Streets. "On the Waterfront" was set in this neighborhood, back when it was a very tough, working pier.

properties.name: The First Tower Fell
properties.description: Posted by InstantaneousAs I was walking to work that morning. I was going East along Houston St., running into the hordes of frantic people pouring up the sidewalks from downtown. I remember seeing a cloud of dust in the distance down one of the streets in SOHO, and asking a woman on the street if a tower had fallen- she just looked at me with a really puzzled expression and didn\'t answer.

properties.name: The Second Tower Fell
properties.description: Posted by InstantaneousI had gotten to work, running into even more worried people pouring up Broadway from downtown. A few of them were covered in dust or debris. Everyone was commenting how cellphones didn\'t work, but Blackberries did. I was on my way to the roof of the 11-story mid-rise office building I used to work in when the second tower went. Now I\'m glad I didn\'t see either collapse with my own eyes.
